text: Thanks for the suggestion <@UMVFWPZ36>! This could be a great way to get the community together and keep some momentum going. Is there interest in this <!channel> for attending or helping to organizing a conference in 2020?

text: I would be excited to participate in such an event, but I'd be much more interested in a symposium or some other forum where the attendees were all actively working in the space.

elements.text: I would be excited to participate in such an event, but I'd be much more interested in a symposium or some other forum where the attendees were all actively working in the space.

text: Can you elaborate on the distinction between a conference vs symposium?

elements.text: Can you elaborate on the distinction between a conference vs symposium?

text: I guess the format (symposium, conference, etc.) can also be discussed and agreed collectively.

elements.text: I guess the format (symposium, conference, etc.) can also be discussed and agreed collectively.

text: I refuse to travel to the States given the current political climate, and I've heard others in tech express the same sentiment about the US and UK as well. The EU would be fantastic.

elements.text: I refuse to travel to the States given the current political climate, and I've heard others in tech express the same sentiment about the US and UK as well. The EU would be fantastic.

text: Canada or Mexico are both good options then :wink:

elements.text: Canada or Mexico are both good options then

text: Co-locating with an established programming conference could make the FOC conference simpler and cheaper to organize.

elements.text: Co-locating with an established programming conference could make the FOC conference simpler and cheaper to organize.

text:
I'd say conference lacks communication between speakers / attendees whereas symposium focuses more on exchange of ideas? I have spoken at conferences and I feel 1) you need to cut more niche / deep contents to accommodate all attendees 2) conversations can only happen in the 10 min breaks or after party and many attendees don't even get the chance to chat with speakers in more depth.

If I'm presenting I'd be very happy to assume attendees are excited about the same kind of ideas I'm interested in, and to know I can have a deeper than over-the-beer conversations afterwards with them.

elements.text:
I'd say conference lacks communication between speakers / attendees whereas symposium focuses more on exchange of ideas? I have spoken at conferences and I feel 1) you need to cut more niche / deep contents to accommodate all attendees 2) conversations can only happen in the 10 min breaks or after party and many attendees don't even get the chance to chat with speakers in more depth.

If I'm presenting I'd be very happy to assume attendees are excited about the same kind of ideas I'm interested in, and to know I can have a deeper than over-the-beer conversations afterwards with them.

text: I was at the Programming Synthesis conference last week, which maybe was more like a symposium. I would say there were ~50 folks there and ~20 spoke either for a few minutes or longer sessions. I think it would be fun to design a smallish conference (fewer than 100, perhaps as few as 50), and have each person speak for perhaps 2 minutes each, about what they are working on/most passionate about. That way you maximize the odds of everyone connecting with the people most relevant to their work, and you can spend most time in conversation and less time sitting in seats  listening

elements.text: I was at the Programming Synthesis conference last week, which maybe was more like a symposium. I would say there were ~50 folks there and ~20 spoke either for a few minutes or longer sessions. I think it would be fun to design a smallish conference (fewer than 100, perhaps as few as 50), and have each person speak for perhaps 2 minutes each, about what they are working on/most passionate about. That way you maximize the odds of everyone connecting with the people most relevant to their work, and you can spend most time in conversation and less time sitting in seats  listening

text: The Programming Synthesis conference very much felt like it was headed that way, and I would go full throttle in that direction (no talks longer than 5 minutes, perhaps maybe a 10 minute keynote or too)

elements.text: The Programming Synthesis conference very much felt like it was headed that way, and I would go full throttle in that direction (no talks longer than 5 minutes, perhaps maybe a 10 minute keynote or too)

text: Two more ideas for brainstorming: something along the lines of <http://StartupSchool.org|StartupSchool.org>'s weekly 1 hour video sessions (where you are paired with 3 other people for a 1 hour video conference and everyone goes around the room giving a quick description of what they are working on; and then another round where you describe your biggest obstacles)

text: and instead of 1 big conference, perhaps a quarterly smaller "coffee club", where you'd just have a location like EU,Mexico,Hawaii,etc, and you do a "coffee tour" of the city....no formal location, no agenda, just laptops, coffee, and facetime
